text: - I'm Nicholas Marwell.

I'm a member of the
Technical Staff at Anthropic.

I think one of the biggest
misconceptions about gen AI
among the general public
is that we really are at the start
of an inflection in scaling.

When we think about what
has made these models great,
it's really the discovery that
scaling the size of the models leads,
these kind of improvements in capabilities

that already exist but also
emergent new capabilities.
And when we think about the inputs
that make models bigger and bigger,

and we're principally talking
about hardware efficiency,
software efficiency and data,

hardware and software
efficiency in particular

are each scaling at
about 2x every two years.
What that means is if you go eight years
into the future from now,

we may have models that
are 256 or so times bigger
than the models we have today,
and that's gonna have massive implications
for what these things can do.

One of the things that I
think is really important

for people to understand about
productionizing these models

is that it's much more
of an empirical science
than it is a theoretical one.
We have kind of best practices
but really the only way to know

whether models are hitting
the right milestones
across all of these categories,
security, safety, efficiency and accuracy,

is to have great evaluations
and to experiment.
And so every great deployment
starts with a great set of evaluations.
And that should let you balance

all of these things as
you try to get to market.
In terms of supporting us and others
on their gen AI journeys,
one of the great things about AWS

is the ability to take kind of
leading edge frontier models

and deploy them with the kind
of confidence in security

and scalability that AWS has
built up in their customers
over the course of almost two decades now.
(upbeat music)
